item.title: The Function Special Interest Group
item.author: idoerg@gmail.com (IF Lab)
item.description:
The mission of the Function Special Interest Group (Function-SIG) is to bring together computational biologists, experimental biologists and biocurators who are dealing with the important problem of gene and gene product function prediction, to share ideas and create collaborations. The Function-SIG holds annual meetings alongside the ISMB. Also, we are conducting the multi-year Critical Assessment of protein Function Annotation, or CAFA, experiment.

The accurate annotation of protein function is key to understanding life at the molecular level. However, with its inherent difficulty and expense, experimental characterization of function cannot scale up to accommodate the vast amount of sequence data already available. The computational annotation of protein function has therefore emerged as a problem at the forefront of bioinformatics. Recently, the availability of genomic-level sequence information for thousands of species, coupled with massive high-throughput experimental data, has created new opportunities as well as challenges for function prediction.

item.title: Publications
item.author: idoerg@gmail.com (IF Lab)
item.description:
Image slider at the start

Function SIG Publications

The automated function prediction SIG looks back at 2013 and prepares for 2014 Bioinformatics 30 (14): 2091-2092., March 2014 Mark N. Wass, Sean D. Mooney, Michal Linial, Predrag Radivojac, and Iddo Friedberg

Selected proceedings from the Automated Function Prediction Meeting (2011) BMC Bioinformatics Volume 13 Supl 3, February 2013 Edited by Iddo Friedberg and Predrag Radivojac

The Second Automated Function Prediction Meeting Proceedings (2006) BMC Bioinformatics Volume 8 Suppl 4, May 2007 Edited by Ana PC Rodrigues, Barry J Grant, Adam Godzik and Iddo Friedberg

The First Automated Function Prediction Meeting Proceedings (2005) Protein Science Volume 15, July 2006 (Last 6 articles in issue) Edited by Iddo Friedberg and Adam Godzik

item.title: CAFA
item.author: idoerg@gmail.com (IF Lab)
item.description: The problem: There are many proteins in the databases for which the sequence is known, but the function is not. The gap between what we know and what we do not know is growing. A major challenge in the field of bioinformatics is to predict the function of a protein from its sequence or structure. At the same time, how can we judge how well these function prediction algorithms are performing?
